Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Network Connectivity and Security for Cooperative Autonomous Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Systems of autonomous vehicles under cooperative control provide versatile platforms for a variety of tasks including environmental monitoring, search and rescue, intelligent transportation, and cooperative surveillance or attack. Performing these tasks requires control or optimization of the system's formation while maintaining network connectivity. Such systems are also potential targets for attack, and so techniques to secure the communications and control processes are important. In this project, techniques from computer networks are coupled with controls techniques to reconfigure the physical formation of a system of autonomous vehicles while maintaining network connectivity by "routing" vehicles through the formation to new positions. This approach is an enabling technology that also allows the network formation to be optimized to increase the efficiency of networked communication. New approaches to securing communication signals are coupled with the ability to transform the physical formation of the system to provide new approaches to achieving communication that is secure against eavesdroppers and robust to hostile jamming. The results of this project will be new algorithms, protocols, and controls techniques for formation control of systems of autonomous vehicles that are more flexible, efficient, and secure than the techniques currently available. These results will be widely applicable to future sensing/monitoring, homeland security, and defense operations involving autonomous systems of ground, air, surface, and underwater vehicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we developed techniques for control of a system of autonomous vehicles that communicate over a wireless network, with all the constraints, impairments, and opportunities created by wireless networks. We developed the first algorithms to take an arbitrary network of identical vehicles and transform it to any desired physical formation (that is still connected by wireless links), where the mapping of which vehicle goes to which position and how that is achieved is all performed by our algorithms without human intervention. All the coordination information is carried over a wireless network, and the ability to communicate among vehicles depends on the spatial formation of the vehicles, which is what is being changed. Thus, the algorithm must ensure that the network is connected at all times during this process, which it does by carefully selecting which vehicles can move, so that a communication backbone is maintained among the vehicles at all times.

Wireless communications often experience losses in connectivity caused by unfavorable signal propagation conditions or interference. We developed techniques to make our control techniques robust to such losses. Another feature of wireless communications is that it is an open communication medium, meaning that anyone can inject wireless signals into the network to disrupt communications. Thus, we also developed approaches to make our control techniques robust to manipulation by bad or malfunctioning agents.

In addition to being vulnerable to bad information injected into the network, wireless networks are also vulnerable to interference or jamming. In the context of control of a system of autonomous vehicles and for many other applications, the objective of the system may be disrupted if interference causes the network to partition, in which it is broken into separate subnetworks that cannot communicate with each other. Thus, we developed techniques to identify weaknesses in the network that allow the network to be partitioned by interference or jamming. We used the knowledge of the vulnerabilities to deploy some autonomous vehicles equipped with radios to act as “helper nodes” to make the network more robust to such interference.

Wireless networks experience congestion when they are carrying too much traffic, and we developed techniques to reduce the amount of information that must be exchanged during the control of a system of autonomous vehicles, and we also developed techniques to optimally assign traffic of a set of users to a set of wireless channels based on the traffic of the users, while accounting for the congestion created by collisions among transmissions.

The techniques developed in this work address the most challenging problems in the control of networked autonomous vehicles that must communicate over wireless networks.
